text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 11.3.37.1 - Revised the title to Program Scope to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
, Background - Added information about the circumstances surrounding the recordkeeping and accounting for disclosures process. Information from prior section
, Background, was incorporated into this new subsection. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities about the recordkeeping and accounting for disclosures process. c. IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities - This IRM applies to all IRS employees and contractors. d. IRM
, Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used acronyms pertaining to the recordkeeping and accounting for disclosures process. e. IRM
, Related Resources - Added related resources applicable to the recordkeeping and accounting process.

Editorial changes have been made throughout to update IRM/statute/organizational references and to make the text easier to follow. Changed names of example entities in text to match Human Capital Office (HCO) guidelines on use of ﬁctitious names. Reworded text to remove passive voice.
Added table to Example in IRM 11.3.37.2(2) to clarify what information is needed in the accounting. Added new (4) to address the records management lifecycle.

Added new (2) to IRM 11.3.37.3.1 to show a list of the required items that must be provided on a record of accounting. Removed paragraph (5) from this same section and added it to information (3). Also removed paragraph (18) from this same section and added it as a Note to (3). Updated addresses in (9) and removed link to the website where these addresses were previously found. Removed items a) and b) from paragraph (15) since that information is not relevant to the for disclosures process. Paragraphs renumbered accordingly to accommodate these changes.

Added new paragraphs (1), (2) (3) and (4) to IRM 11.3.37.3.2 to provide clariﬁcation on the narrative record of accounting process and show a list of the required items that must be provided on a narrative record of accounting. Some of the info in the prior paragraphs was incorporated in the new language. Subsequent paragraphs were renumbered accordingly. Updated (5) to add guidance on processing narrative records of accounting.

) Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section provides guidance on recordkeeping and accounting for disclosures as governed by Subsection the Privacy Act of
a, and the Internal Revenue Code IRC §
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Director of Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safe- guards (GLDS), is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (

) Program Owner: The Disclosure office, under GLDS is responsible for the closure program and guidance. Each IRS organization is responsible for ensuring its employees are aware of and follow Servicewide Disclosure (
) Primary Stakeholders: All IRS Business Units have responsibility for record- keeping and accounting for disclosures made pursuant to subsection (c) of Privacy Act and IRC §
)(A). This responsibility extends to manual well as electronic applications in which accountable disclosures of tax tion occur. (
) The system used to account for disclosures of returns and return complies with two laws: a. Subsection (c) of the Privacy Act of

) Due to these two statutes, individuals may determine whether the IRS disclosed Federal Tax Information (FTI) or Privacy Act information about The IRS must record what FTI or Privacy Act information it discloses about taxpayer. (

) Subsection (c) of the Privacy Act requires the IRS to keep an accurate ac- counting of each disclosure of information from a tax or nontax system of records. A system of records is a group of records regarding individuals that retrievable by a unique identiﬁer corresponding to those individuals. The publishes systems of records periodically in the Federal Register. View the systems of records at: Privacy Act System of Records Notices. (
) The procedures in this chapter address only tax systems of records. To account for disclosures from nontax systems, see IRM
)(A) and Subsection (c) of the Privacy Act overlap regarding a particular disclosure, the accounting requirements of §
)(A) will govern. Example: IRS provides corporate income tax returns to the Department of in response to an ex parte order submitted under IRC §
). Corporate income tax returns meet the deﬁnition of returns under IRC

Primary Stakeholders: All IRS Business Units have responsibility for record- keeping and accounting for disclosures made pursuant to subsection (c) of the Privacy Act and IRC §6103(p)(3)(A). This responsibility extends to manual as well as electronic applications in which accountable disclosures of tax informa- tion occur.
IRS provides corporate income tax returns to the Department of Justice in response to an ex parte order submitted under IRC §
). Corporate income tax returns meet the deﬁnition of returns under IRC §
Therefore, the IRS employee accounts for their disclosure in ac- cordance with the requirements of IRC §
)(A) even though they do not fall within a system of record deﬁned by the Privacy Act.

In accordance with disclosure authority IRC §6103(h)(3)(A), IRS refers federal tax case to the Department of Justice for criminal prosecution and includes in the referral package the 2015 and 2016 income tax

returns of John Doe along with the related investigative ﬁles. (c) of the Privacy Act requires an accounting for these disclosures. However the IRS employee does not make an accounting since IRC §6103(p)(3)(A) exempts disclosures made under IRC §6103(h)(3)(A) from the accounting requirement.
(c) of the Privacy Act requires an accounting for these disclosures. However the IRS employee does not make an accounting since IRC §
)(A) requires the IRS to account for all disclosures of return information furnished under a subsection of IRC §
are exempt from the accounting quirements as deﬁned in IRC §

) All IRS employees who are responsible for making an accountable of tax information are also responsible for completing the accounting for disclosures, following the procedures in this IRM or their local procedures. Contact the Disclosure Help Desk for any questions regarding the ing or accounting for disclosures of tax information. Compliance with this requirement may be validated through Quality Reviews. (
) The following items govern the authority pertaining to recordkeeping and counting for disclosures of information: • Subsection (c) of the Privacy Act of

) All IRS employees, contractors and state and federal agencies use this help comply with the recordkeeping and accounting for disclosures of tax mation as governed by the Privacy Act and the Internal Revenue Code. (

When accounting for disclosures, determine how many accounting records to prepare by identifying the number of sources used to furnish information.
Note: The IRS assigns an ADP source code to information collected, developed or maintained by a function.
The Privacy Act governs tax information of individuals; see Exhibit
for these sources. For tax information not governed by the Privacy Act, the sources are those nontax systems of records listed in Exhibit
Exception: When disclosing information from a tax system of records, use the following guidelines to determine the maximum number of accounting records to prepare:
one accounting for the return or return information involved and one for each function whose systems of records are disclosed

This procedure is consistent with the spirit of IRC §6103(p)(3)(A) and sub- section (c) of the Privacy Act. When disclosing from multiple systems of records, it is more practical to limit the number of sources in order to avoid confusion over the amount of information disclosed.

Example: The Department of Justice is conducting a nontax federal criminal grand jury and makes an Ex Parte Court Order request under IRC §6103(i)(1) for the 2016 individual income tax return and related ﬁles and records of
John Doe. After conducting a thorough search, the IRS employee locates and discloses the following information for tax year 2016:
The IRS employee prepares an accounting record for the following:

Taxpayer Delinquency Account File. (Although a disclosure was also made from the lien ﬁle, most of the information disclosed from Collection ﬁles was obtained from the TDA ﬁle) and Examination Administrative File. (The greatest amount of information was disclosed from the administrative ﬁle.)
An accounting record for ABC Company indicates the IRS disclosed ABC’s Forms

to the Department of Labor. Thus, the taxpayer’s account in the accounting ﬁle records four disclo- sures. For disclosures involving multiple years and functional systems, the taxpayers account in the accounting ﬁle records accountings equal to the number of years multiplied by the number of functional systems.

An accounting record for ABC Company indicates the IRS disclosed ABC’s Forms 1120 for tax years 2013-2016 to the Department of Labor. Thus, the taxpayer’s account in the accounting ﬁle records four disclo- sures. For disclosures involving multiple years and functional systems, the taxpayers account in the accounting ﬁle records accountings equal the number of years multiplied by the number of functional systems.

to the Department of Labor. Thus, the taxpayer’s account in the accounting ﬁle records four disclo- sures. For disclosures involving multiple years and functional systems, the taxpayers account in the accounting ﬁle records accountings equal to the number of years multiplied by the number of functional systems. Refer to Document 12990, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule 8 – Administrative and Organizational Records, Items 44 and 70, (Job No. N1-58-05-2) to ensure records, in hard copy and electronic format, are appropriately managed, retained, and archived in accor- dance with the National Archives and Records Administration approved retention and disposition authority. Also refer to IRMs 1.15, Records and Infor- mation Management series for compliance with records and ﬁles management lifecycle (hardcopy and electronic), including creation, maintenance, retrieval, preservation and disposition of all records to avoid inadvertent/unlawful de- struction of records.
Note: Capturing this same information also satisﬁes the accounting requirements of

Disclosure of Official The IRS can account for the disclosure of returns/return information either manually or electronically. Generally, the IRS electronically posts disclosure information to a disclosure accounting ﬁle that is an adjunct to the Individual Master File (IMF) and Business Master File (BMF). The business component that discloses the records is responsible for preparing the record of accounting. State or federal agencies making permis- sible disclosures to other state or federal agencies pursuant to an IRC §
)(B) agreement will maintain a permanent system of recording dis- closures and provide to the IRS within
days after the close of each year, a narrative of accounting for all disclosures of returns and return tion made to the receiving agency, as required by
Disclosure personnel are available to provide technical assistance. A record of accounting for disclosure of returns/return information includes the following items: a. Name Control: The ﬁrst

alpha and/or numeric characters of the tax- payer’s last name (in the case of individuals) or the ﬁrst four alpha numeric characters of the business name (in the case of partnership, porations, etc.) b. Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number: The IRS identiﬁes a taxpayer’s business account through the Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN). IRS identiﬁes an individual taxpayer through the Social Security Number (SSN). c. Tax Period: The Service uses a six digit code to indicate the end of the tax period for a given return. The ﬁrst four digits represent the year (YYYY) and the next two digits represent the month (MM). d. Disclosure Date: Date of the disclosure (MMDDYYYY). The Service uses an eight digit code to indicate the date. The ﬁrst two digits the month (MM), the next two digits represent the day (DD) and the last four digits represent the year (YYYY). e. Nature of Disclosure Code: A one digit code that represents the of disclosure, i.e. a verbal disclosure, an electronic disclosure, of records, or paper copy of record. See Exhibit
, Multiple Record of Disclosure for a listing of the nature of disclosure codes. f. Agency Code: A three digit code assigned to the agency, person or receiving a disclosure. See Exhibit

, Federal Agency Codes. Note: Not all agency codes reﬂected in the Exhibit can be used to post a disclosure accounting, care should be taken to use correct agency codes to ensure accurate accountings. g. Purpose Code: A two digit code that identiﬁes the authorizing statute the disclosure. See Exhibit
, Multiple Record of Disclosure for listing of the purpose codes. h. ADP Source Code: A three digit code identifying the system of record the disclosure. See Exhibit
, Frequently Used ADP Source Codes Tax Systems of Records (Individuals Covered by the Privacy Exhibit
, ADP Source Codes - Tax Systems of Records (Systems Governed by the Privacy Act), and Exhibit
, ADP Source Code - Tax Information (Not Governed by the Privacy Act) for listed ADP source codes.

)(A). Example: A state tax agency requests a copy of the

) The Martinsburg or Detroit Computing Centers make disclosures through Governmental Liaison Data Exchange Program (GLDEP) that are for electronically (e.g., certain disclosures to state tax agencies, for state administration purposes under IRC §

) Disclosure accountings are also electronically generated through the use AIMS. AIMS is used to account for the automatic disclosure of copies of Revenue Agent Reports provided for by implementing agreements IRS and state tax agencies. (

) Once a disclosure is accounted for, subsequent disclosures made from the same source, in response to the same request, and in the same manner the initial disclosure, do not have to be accounted for again. Example: On September
an IRS employee provides return information from a Criminal Investigation administrative ﬁle (a portion of the Agent’s Report) to the U.S. Attorney pursuant to an IRC §
Certain disclosures that are made electronically include an automated account- ing and do not require the preparation of Form 5466-B.
an IRS employee provides return information from a Criminal Investigation administrative ﬁle (a portion of the Agent’s Report) to the U.S. Attorney pursuant to an IRC §
) request concerning the ABC Company. An entry is made on Form
-B to record the disclosure. On September
the IRS employee provides additional return information (copies of ABC Company’s checks, obtained by the Special Agent from a bank) in response to the same IRC §

) request. No new accountings required. A description of the material and date of the disclosure are retained in the ﬁle, or the documents could be stamped or noted to indicate the date and recipient of the disclosure.
Consider using a narrative record of accounting in lieu of Form

-B when accounting for a large number of records. Use the narrative accounting method where: a. Resource savings would result. b. The posting of individual accountings to taxpayer accounts (Transaction Code (TC)
) is unavailable to the taxpayer, i.e. disclosures made under a condition of disclosure as stated in
). Note: Submit a narrative record of accounting for Ex Parte court orders that are sealed or not a matter of public record. The

-B ac- counting places a Transaction Code on the taxpayer account that can be requested and/or released on a transcript of account. A narrative accounting avoids the potential for taxpayer notiﬁcation that their information has been disclosed, prior to the order being made a public record.
Submit a narrative record of accounting for Ex Parte court orders that are sealed or not a matter of public record. The

-B ac- counting places a Transaction Code on the taxpayer account that can be requested and/or released on a transcript of account. A narrative accounting avoids the potential for taxpayer notiﬁcation that their information has been disclosed, prior to the order being made a public record.
Note: Decide whether a narrative accounting is appropriate on a case by case basis with the business unit supervisor.

) A narrative record of accounting for disclosure of returns/return information summarizes the disclosures made includes the following items: a. Category and number of taxpayers: IMF - number of IMF taxpayers whose information was disclosed BMF - number of BMF taxpayers whose information was disclosed Tax years - list tax periods disclosed. Provide listing separately for and BMF if both are reported in the narrative accounting. Total number of disclosures (Number of IMF taxpayers, “+” number of BMF taxpayers “+” total tax periods disclosed = total number of sures) b. Date of disclosure c. Description of documents disclosed: Brieﬂy describe what was (e.g., Transcripts, lack of record, copy of tax return) d. Purpose of disclosure: Select appropriate purpose code from Exhibit

e. Name of agency receiving the information: Provide name and address the agency receiving the information f. Location of IRS office retaining a copy of disclosed information: IRS office location where a record of the disclosed information is tained g. Nature of documents disclosed: Describe method of disclosure (e.g., verbal disclosure, an electronic disclosure, inspection of records, copy of record) (
) The business component that owns the records must prepare the for disclosures. State or federal agencies making permissible disclosures to other state or federal agencies pursuant to an IRC §
)(B) must also make any required accountings and forward their narrative to the IRS. Disclosure personnel are available to provide technical assistance. (
) The office that owns the records will make a narrative report and retain a of the report in order to satisfy section (c)(
) of the Privacy Act and IRC §

)(A). Forward the narrative record of accounting to the Business Unit coordinator, who will forward total disclosure counts to the propriate Disclosure Policy and Program Operations (D-PPO) Analyst, with copy maintained by the office making the disclosure. To the maximum possible, retain documentation that would enable identiﬁcation of the taxpayers in the event it is necessary to construct such a list at some future time. (
) Note the ﬁle or maintain a copy of the accounting document to show the pilation of the disclosure accounting. (
) GLDS, Disclosure Policy and Program Operations is responsible for an annual report of the authorized disclosures accounted for under IRC §
)(B) and (C) deﬁne the scope, content and timing for the report. IRS must submit the report no later than
days after the close each calendar year, generally by March
for all accountable disclosures made during the prior calendar year. The report is a compilation of the of records disclosed under the reportable provisions of IRC §
)(A). IRS functional business units report the record counts to D-PPO both cally and manually. See IRM
below for processing guidance. Internal Revenue Manual
A narrative record of accounting for disclosure of returns/return information summarizes the disclosures made includes the following items:

a. Category and number of taxpayers: IMF - number of IMF taxpayers whose information was disclosed BMF - number of BMF taxpayers whose information was disclosed Tax years - list tax periods disclosed. Provide listing separately for and BMF if both are reported in the narrative accounting. Total number of disclosures (Number of IMF taxpayers, “+” number of BMF taxpayers “+” total tax periods disclosed = total number of sures) b. Date of disclosure c. Description of documents disclosed: Brieﬂy describe what was (e.g., Transcripts, lack of record, copy of tax return) d. Purpose of disclosure: Select appropriate purpose code from Exhibit

e. Name of agency receiving the information: Provide name and the agency receiving the information f. Location of IRS office retaining a copy of disclosed information: IRS office location where a record of the disclosed information is tained g. Nature of documents disclosed: Describe method of disclosure (e.g., verbal disclosure, an electronic disclosure, inspection of records, copy of record) The business component that owns the records must prepare the

IRC §6103(p)(3)(B) and (C) deﬁne the scope, content and timing for submitting the report. IRS must submit the report no later than 90 days after the close of each calendar year, generally by March 31 for all accountable disclosures made during the prior calendar year. The report is a compilation of the number of records disclosed under the reportable provisions of IRC §6103(p)(3)(A). IRS functional business units report the record counts to D-PPO both systemi- cally and manually. See IRM 11.3.37.4.1 below for processing guidance.

) The D-PPO lead analyst will contact and engage the JCT each year for into and feedback needed for changes to the scope and content of the The D-PPO analysts will send a request for disclosure counts in December each of the business units and external sources that provided data from the prior year’s report providing any additional guidance or instructions. The business unit point of contact should timely advise D-PPO of any personnel changes prior to the annual engagement. (
) Throughout the year, but only as necessary, the D-PPO analyst will legislative changes to IRC §

, new agreements, memoranda of under- standing, and new systems for disclosing return information to determine if accountings are required. The D-PPO analyst will work with all IRS units to provide awareness training in properly accounting for disclosures required. (
) The report package will contain: a. Cover transmittal letter b. Report of disclosures under IRC §
)(B) c. Public report of disclosures under IRC §
)(C), including ate reference and footnotes, and a brief explanation of the general purposes for each IRC section included in the report d. Internal transmittal documents; Form
-A, Note to Reviewer, and any other explanatory documents to cilitate the review and approval of the report package (

) After compiling all data and preparing the report, PGLD management, Chief Counsel (Procedure & Administration), the Deputy Commissioner for Opera- tions Support, and the Commissioner’s Chief of Staff will review and the report package for the Commissioner’s signature. Legislative Affairs delivers the report to the JCT Chief of Staff. (

) Disclosure Policy and Program Operations relies on business and functional units that make accountable disclosures to maintain records and report the Input into the number of disclosures, either systemically within various applications or Accounting manually. (

)(A) requires, with limited exceptions enumerated in the the IRS to maintain a permanent system of standardized records or ings of all requests for inspection or disclosure of returns or return These systems may be automated within an information technology or manually maintained. (
) The exceptions are speciﬁed by IRC §
subsection in IRC If the subsection is not speciﬁcally listed in IRC §
)(A), employees making authorized disclosures must account for the disclosure. Example: IRC §
(e), disclosures of tax returns or return information to a person with a material interest (e.g. the taxpayer’s return to the taxpayer) is listed so no accounting is required. IRC §
(d), sures to state tax agencies is not listed so any disclosure under this subsection requires accounting.
(e), disclosures of tax returns or return information to a person with a material interest (e.g. the taxpayer’s return to the taxpayer) is listed so no accounting is required. IRC §
(d), disclo- sures to state tax agencies is not listed so any disclosure under this subsection requires accounting.
Unauthorized disclosures are not reported in the annual JCT report.
) If the IRS employee prepares and submits Form
-B, Multiple Record of Disclosure, the employee’s actions are complete as that process captures disclosure accounting in the Disclosure Masterﬁle. (
) If the IRS employee making an accountable disclosure does not prepare and submit Form
-B, additional steps are necessary to ensure the JCT captures the accountings. (
) Each business unit is responsible for developing procedures for compiling narrative accounting memoranda or other recordation accounting for disclo- sures and providing summaries to D-PPO. (
) Business units or functions must submit their summary of accountings to D-PPO no later than January
st of each year. D-PPO encourages earlier more frequent reporting (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, or ad hoc) if the cumstances allow. (

) Examples of data sources and functions include, but are not limited to: • Disclosure Areas East and West – Technical Advisors will compile a summary narrative accounting report from their respective Disclosure Offices for disclosures not accounted for on previously submitted

-B. • GLDS Data Services – will compile a summary and detailed report of accountable disclosures made through the GLDEP, the Reimbursable Programs, and related extracts. • Information Technology will provide a compilation summary and report of all disclosures reported from the Disclosure Masterﬁle. • Statistics of Income, a function of Research, Applied Analytics & tics (RAAS) will provide a compilation summary and detailed report of all statistical disclosures made under IRC §

(f), or any other project from which accountable disclosures are made, including a brief explanation of each project. • Large Business & International (LB&I) will provide a summary and detailed report of all bulk and speciﬁc disclosures to competent ties under IRC §
). • Other business units and functions that provide reports of disclosures for various programs and projects include; Examination Operational Automated Database (EOAD), SS-
Determinations, Excise Summary Terminal Activity Reporting System (EXSTARS)/Joint Operations (JOC), TE/GE/
(c), and the Affordable Care Act (ACA). • Excluded from this list are disclosures reported systemically into the Disclosure Masterﬁle (DMF) or through the use of Form

Section Description IMF/BMF check box To reﬂect IMF accountings mark the IMF box. To reﬂect BMF accountings mark the BMF box. Note: Account for IMF/BMF disclosures on separate forms. Alpha Numeric SC Block No entry of information needed. Campus processing use only. Number Document Locator Number No entry of information needed. Campus processing use only. (DLN) DLN Year No entry of information needed. Campus processing use only. Batch Ctr. No. No entry of information needed. Campus processing use only. Initiated By (Name and Title) Print or type name and title of person making the disclosure. Functional Symbols and Enter the organizational symbols of the function making the disclosure. Office Code Reviewed By (Name) Optional, but enter the initials of Disclosure Staff employee delegated to perform a quality review sampling of Form 5466-B. Master File Transcript (MFT) No entry of information needed, entry is already preprinted on the form. Account Code Transaction Code No entry of information needed, entry is already preprinted on the form. Name Control For IMF accounting, enter the ﬁrst four characters of the taxpayer’s last name. For BMF accounting, enter the ﬁrst four characters of the business name. If name is unknown, enter four “x’s” (xxxx). SSN/EIN Enter the Social Security Number or Employer Identiﬁcation Number as applicable. If the SSN or EIN is unknown, complete a narrative record of accounting.Toaccountfor disclosures of Form 706 and Form 709, handwrite a “0” in the shaded area on the Form 5466-B after the last digit of the SSN. The “0” is necessary for the computer to accept the identiﬁcation number in an SSN format. Form 706 and Form 709 are BMF forms, however an SSN is used for the TIN. Tax Period Enter tax period disclosed in YYYYMM format. For disclosures involving more than one year, enter each tax period on a separate line. Record of Disclosure Section Description • 35 - Pursuant to a sealed court order submitted under IRC §6103(i)(1). Use Code 16 if court order is not sealed. Note: All IRC §6103(i)(1) orders should be considered sealed in the absence of a clear and unambiguous indication they are unsealed. • 36-39 - Reserved • 40 - Pursuant to IRC §6103(i)(3)(C)(i) to Federal law enforcement agencies in connection with terrorism. • 41 - Pursuant to IRC §6103(i)(3)(C)(ii) to the Attorney General to apply for an ex parte order approved under IRC §6103(i)(7)(D). • 42 - Pursuant to IRC §6103(i)(7)(A)(i) to Federal law enforcement agencies in connection with terrorism. • 43 - Pursuant to IRC §6103(i)(7)(B) to certain Federal agencies in connection with intelligence activities regarding terrorism. • 44 - Pursuant to IRC §6103(i)(7)(C) to Federal Officers for terrorism related purposes in response to a Court Order. See Code 45 for sealed orders. • 45 - Pursuant to a sealed court order submitted under IRC §6103(i)(7)(C). • 99 - Reversal of Prior Recordation-in the event it is determined that a disclosure was recorded in error, e.g., posted to another in- dividual’ s account, input an identical entry on Form 5466-B except enter Purpose Code 99. Interpretation of this transaction will signify that disclosure accounted for by the original transaction was not made as indicated. May also be used to reverse accountings input on AIMS.
